informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ta: Takin are a genus of 'Goat Antelope' found in the Himilayas! They are a very important animal in Asian Culture, being the national animal of Bhutan and considered National Treasures in China! Sadly, Takin are threatened by overhunting and the destruction of its natural habitat, often Takin horns can be seen at illegal wildlife trade.

Mishmi takin are a subspecies of Takin found in the sparse Bamboo Forests of Northeast India, Myanmar and China. Mishmi Takin grow a thick, secondary coat to protect them from the rain and the harsh sub-alpine climates they thrive within. They are currently listed as Endangered by the IUCN Red List of Species.

Golden Takin are a subspecies of Takin dwelling only in the Qinling Mountains of China's Shaanxi Province. This particular subspecies lives in alpine forests of altitudes of up to 3,500m! They are currently listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List of Species due to deforestation and excessive hunting.

Sichuan Takin are a subspecies of Takin listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List of Species. Native to the dense forests of Tibet and China's Sichuan Province, it can be differentiated from its close cousin, the Golden Takin, by its darker coat and colour. Sichuan Takin are also family animals, found in large groups of up to 4 generations!

Bhutan Takin are a subspecies of Takin listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List of Species. Native to the mixed forests of Bhutan, India, Western India & China, this particular species is native to altitudes of between 1,000 & 4,500 metres. Bhutan Takins are diurnal, active in the day, resting in the heat on particularly sunny days!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.we: Bongo are the largest forest antelope worldwide! Native to Western & Central Africa, Bongo are recognised by their vibrant reddish-brown coat - that is if you can find them! Bongos are so secretive, it's very difficult to get an estimate of their population! Unfortunately, Bongo are threatened by habitat loss & bush-meat hunting.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.lo: Another African Savannah staple, Lowland Nyala are considered the most sexually dimorphic antelope on the planet - males boast spiral horns with dark brown or grey fur.  On the other hand, females and young have maroon or rufous brown coats, no horns, and ten white vertical stripes on each side.  Nyala are also a very timid species, being very cautious & shy when approaching open spaces, usually only being seen at Water Holes.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.sa: The Felonious Gru of the animal world, Saiga are recognisable via their huge noses. These nasal accessories have a practical use however, as a source of warmth in the cold winters of the Eurasian Steppes. Unfortunately for these gentle creatures, they are very rare and are practically unheard of in captivity, although it is up for debate whether that is better or worse for these prehistoric fossils.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ti: Tibetan Antelope, Chiru, Asian ZebraGoat, this animal is known by many names (ok I made up the last one) These horned hoofstock are group animals, the largest group found being 100+! Listed as Endangered for a long while, Tibetan Antelope have made a comeback recently, well deserved for an animal devoted enough to travel over 300km to migrate!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.se: Thanks to its extra-long legs, stretched-out neck, and huge ears, the serval is sometimes called the “cat of spare parts.” But put together, their bizarre body parts make them surprisingly successful hunters. In fact, Servals have a success hunting rate of roughly 50%, which makes it the third most successful feline. Lions are only successful anywhere between 15-25%, which means the average serval has twice the success rate of the best lions on the african plains!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.em: Big, Brown and Boysterous, Emus are both the second largest bird and the second largest ratite, only being topped by the ostrich. Although being such troublemakers they caused a war (yes, literally), Emus are commonly kept in the United States. To top off the list, Emus are unbelievably fast, travelling at up to 30 miles per hour!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ki: Small, Cute, Fluffy - what more could you ask for in a bird? Well, the Kiwi can tell you. A beautiful long beak and an attitude to life that resembles my wake-up on Monday, these little birds are another example of New Zealand's Birds. Kiwis are amazing for other reasons too, the eggs they lay are up to 20% of the female's weight!  The largest in proportion of ANY bird.

North Island Brown Kiwis are a species of Kiwi found in the humid pine forests of New Zealand's North Island. With a population estimated of 35,000 individuals, North Island Brown are the most common species of Kiwi in the Wild and in Captivity. Hence, they are currently listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List of species, with their main threat being invasive predators.

The second largest species of Kiwi, South Island Brown Kiwis are found in the dense subtropical forests of, surprise surprise, New Zealand's South Island. Currently listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List Of Species, they are threatened by habitat loss, poaching and invasive mammals such as Stoats and Brush Tailed Possums. However their population is settled at 34,000 individuals.

Okarito Kiwi are a species of Kiwi native to a restricted area of the Okarito Forest, located on the West Coast of New Zealand's South Island. They have a very small population, estimated at 600 individuals so are rare in both the wild and in captivity. Classified as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List, these birds are supported by efforts such as Operation Nest Egg (ONE) at raising their populations.

The largest of the Kiwi species, Great Spotted Kiwis are found in the mountainous forests of the northwestern South Island. The species is highly aggressive, unlike other Kiwis, and displays nocturnal behaviours. Currently, their population is estimated at around 16,000, making them one of the rarer kiwi species. Great Spotted Kiwis are registered as Vulnerable by the IUCN Red List.

The smallest of all the Kiwi species, Little Spotted Kiwis are native to dense bamboo forests throughout New Zealand. Similarly to other Kiwi species, they are nocturnal, spending their days in burrows. Despite being the most widespread species of Kiwi, they unfortunately only have a small population of 1670 individuals and are classified as Near Threatened by the IUCN Red List.

Not technically a species, however a genetic mutation of the North Island Brown Kiwis, Manukura was the first of three pure white kiwis born in captivity, and she was born in the Pukaha National Wildlife Centre, where she was named by a Rangitane leader - her name being the Maori word for 'Cheifly Status' Unfortunately, she died in December of 2020 after surgery.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.fe: The smallest of the best species of mammal (no this is not a mistake!), the Fennec Fox is one of the most recognisable animal species out there! With two dinner plates stuck to the side of their head, the Fennec Fox is a standout at any good Desert exhibit!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.mo: Mouse Deer, or Chevrotains, are the smallest species of hoofed mammals in the world! The majority of Mouse Deer live in Asia, but the Water Chevrotian is native to parts of Africa. There are 10 total species of chevrotian, most are marked as Least Concern by the IUCN Red List, although all species live in secrecy, with some (like the Vietnamese) only being rediscovered recently!

One of the larger members of its family, these pint-sized deer enjoy both dry land and wetlands. Like most small deer, it uses elongated canines during the breeding season rather than antlers.  This allows ease traversing in the thick forest vegetation!

This species is recognizable by striking white spots and splotches and is smaller than most others in its family.  However, like much of its family, they prefer a nocturnal lifestyle, enjoying leaves and shoots when it is safer and easier to hide in the event of predation.

Javan Mouse Deer, altho secluded on the island of Java, prefer higher elevated forests, with an average ground level of half a mile above sea level! They are also known to be verified as a crepuscular animal, meaning they are active mostly at dawn and dusk!

This diurnal ungulate is seen as more than just a cute animal.  In folklore, specifically in Indonesia and Malaysia, they are portrayed as Sang Kancil who uses cunning and intelligence to overcome obstacles and opponents much larger than him! Sadly, their tales might end as introduced species, such as dogs, threaten the population.

Once thought to be a subspecies of the Greater Mouse Deer, they have since been separated due to skull morphology differences in 2004! Staying low until nightfall to feast on dense undergrowth vegetation, this small hoofstock is at severe risk from bushmeat for locals and deforestation for human agriculture.

Adapting to rapid changes in its environment, this Chevrotain species has learned to coexist with human development and exist despite the desire to trap and use them for bushmeat.  In modern literature, this species was separated from other similar members: the Indian Mouse Deer and the Yellow Striped Mouse Deer!

Also known as the Silver-Backed Chevrotain, this elusive species has been hiding from scientists for a century, with only 2 sightings occurring in 1910 and 1990!  This information, paired with demands for logging and bushmeat, has put the species into the unknown of population and possible extinction, although a camera trap in 2019 has spotted this shadow of the forest!

This species is not only the largest in its family, but the only species to be found outside of Asia! Water Mouse Deer also display a rare dimorphism among mammals, where the females are noticeably larger than males.  This nocturnal animal is so reliant on water, it is said that it stays within a 250m radius of any body of water.

Named in honor of Sir Walter James Franklin Williamson, this species falls into the same problem as the Vietnamese Mouse Deer: unknown population counts and rarity of viewing. However, modern research has shown that the deer do exist, but move locales depending on larger herbivores in the area, such as Sambar Deer and Wild Boar!

Being discovered only in 2005, this Chevrotain species is known for their caramel coat with light yellow stripes alongside the animal’s flanks.  While its range does overlap with the Sri Lankan Spotted Mouse Deer, these animals are separate species through heavy analysis of its evolution and lineage known as the Phylogenetic Species Concept!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ho: Pink, Pink Pink. Hoopoe stand out against the dark and dull colours of most British Birds, being a rare example of a bird occuring in Asia, Europe & Africa! To add to their uniqueness, Eurasian Hoopoes are active during the day spending most of the time on the ground probing for grubs and insects. They are solitary foragers who typically feed on the ground, very different to most European Birds.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ma: Not Ocelots, not Leopards, not Jaguars, these beauties are Margays!  Native to South America (with the same range as 2 of those species, you can see why they're easily mistaken!) , Margay are one of the more arboreal species of small cat. Why do they spend their time in the trees? Well their abilities to turn their ankles 180 degrees and jump 12 feet may be factors, aswell as their advanced eyesight which also helps them to traverse at night, being a nocturnal species!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.sl: One of the smallest species of bears, the Sloth Bear is a shaggy coated insectivore found across the Indian Subcontinent. Sloth Bears, like most bears, are solitary animals, however are sometimes spotted in groups when food is plentiful! George Shaw, a 20th century explorer, discovered this species in 1971, naming it 'Ursine bradypus' - meaning slow foot. 'Bradypus' is the genus of 3 sloth species, as Shaw believed them to be related! Hence the name, Sloth Bear!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ha: With their round cheeks and fuzzy bodies, domesticated hamsters are one of the most popular pets. Despite this, Eurasian Hamsters are one of the rarest species of rodent, classified as Critically Endangered by the IUCN Red List! As scientists warn the tiny rodent could be gone in 30 years, efforts to reintroduce and educate about these cute and cuddly creatures are on the rise, even featuring in David Attenborough's 'Seven Worlds, One Planet'! The Eurasian Hamster was a sponsor by ThePidgeyPerson.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.pa: Pallas Cats are a small, long haired cat found in the deserts and rocky regions of Tibet and Siberia! With a scientific name meaning 'ugly-eared', this cat's ears are one of its distinguishing features, along with fur so soft, you'd think it'd been picked out of a Gift Shop! Despite this soft and fluffy look, Pallas Cats are actually one of the lighter species of small cats, typically weighing under 12 pounds - yet their dense fur makes them appear much larger! The Pallas Cat was a sponsor by ThePidgeyPerson.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ta: Tamarins are a group of smaller, tree dwelling New World monkeys that primarily inhabit tropical rainforests. With dexterous hands and long tails that measure up to 17cm, these small primates are very specially adapted to climbing and are a very common animal in most zoos. Tamarins are related to Marmosets, another similar looking primate, and are constantly confused with eachother, there are over 2 dozen species of Tamarin, and just under 2 dozen marmosets, so its easy to lose track!

Emerging from the depths of the ZAWA Animal Vote, the Cotton Top Tamarin is one of the coolest and rarest tamarins, listed as Critically Endangered by the IUCN. These guys are named for the shock of white hair upon their heads, a look reminiscent of a certain Albert Einstein. Cotton Top Tanarins are one of the staple or 'flagship' species of Tamarin

Another funky looking little guy, the Emperor Tamarin is easily distinguished by its long white whiskers that sweep back from its mouth to form a mustache shape! They are belived to have been named after German emperor Wilhelm II who also wore a thick moustache.

They just get better! Red-Handed Tamarins boast an orange-red pair of gloves on their hands and feet, quite the opposite to their pure black fur! Despite lacking a prehensile tail, they can still leap between branches with remarkable dexterity and control!

Pied Tamarins are an endangered species of primate found in northwest brazil. The yoda looking species, who also wear a white-suit-looking coat on their upper half, also go by 'Brazillian bare-faced tamarins', but that's too long to write over and over, so we just call them Pied Tamarins!

No, it isn't a Goeldi's Monkey, and it isn't a Red-Handed Tamarin, despite once being considered a sub species! The Eastern Black Handed Tamarin is endemic to Brazil's Amazonian lowland forests, with a similar range and look to the red handed, just without the gloves. Hence, the confusion between the species!

With its distinct white feet, the White Footed Tamarin stands out against the lush greenery of the rainforest - measuring between 23-30cm in length, this dude is a small yet extremely vital component of its ecosystem - hunting bugs, eggs and vegetation, and providing food for other Brazillian Carnivores.

Almost definitely the most well known Tamarin species, Golden Lion Tamarins are small, social primates with red-gold coats and long manes. They live in the coastal regions of brazil, where their numbers once dwindled to just 200! Thanks to intense conservation however, their numbers are bouncing back & recovering.

Golden-Headed Lion Tamarins closely resemble other species of tamarins; relatively large canines, small heads & small bodies. These tamarins communicate in various different ways, vocalisations are based on activity, behaviour and even individual tamarin personalities!

Black Lion Tamarins are one of 4 lion tamarin species. Not dissimilar to the other 3, they are very rare and extremely threatened by habitat loss and poaching. Unfortunately,  these guys are extremely difficult to keep and look after in captivity - the only captive breeding group of Black Lion Tamarins outside of South America are found at the Jersey Zoo, who have been working with them for over 3 decades.

The Black-faced Lion Tamarin, also known as Superagüi Lion Tamarin, is a small New-World primate in the Callitrichidae family. It is an endangered species native to the coastal forests of southeastern Brazil. These guys have some very interesting abilities that helped them to adapt; the Black-faced Lion Tamarin has non-opposable thumbs and long fingers for catching fruit and insects, and claw-like nails for digging insects from under tree bark.

The Moustached tamarin gets its name from the lack of coloration in the facial hair around the mouth, which resembles a moustache.  However that's not the only thing that separates them from other species; all moustached tamarins have excellent spatial memory and can quickly identify and remember the location of fruit trees. These guys are territorial but have been observed in association with groups of Saddleback Tamarins too!

The Geoffrey's Tamarin,  also known as the Rufous-Naped or Red Crested Tamarin, is one of the smallest species of Tamarin, and the smallest primate found in Panama, part of its South & Central America distribution. These animals are extremely easy to distinguish compared to other species; They have a thick stripe of white on their head, sprouting a very unique hairstyle!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ca: Caracals are a medium sized wildcat known for roaming the deserts and savannahs of Africa and the Middle East. All cats are regal, of course, however the caracal actually seems to have a crown! its large, pointed ears are tipped with black tufts, and are a trademark of their species. These ears each have over 20 muscles that swivel around like satellite dishes to detect their prey. The Caracal was a sponsor by CinnamonGames!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.sp: One of the most recognisable reptiles worldwide, whilst also being one of the most mistaken species, Spectacled Caiman live on the riverbeds and banks of the Amazon Basin. Unfortunately, these beautiful beasts are under threat, from humans and from other reptile species. The worst case of this is Tegus, who destroy up to 80% of the spectacled_caiman nests annualy.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.gu: Confusingly, there are 4 species of camelid native, or originated from South America. Its not a Vicuña, or a Llama, or an Alpaca - The Guanaco is one of the largest terrestrial mammals found in South America. Their size also correlates to their temper - Like all other 6 species of camelid, Guanacos spit. A lot. Even the chulengos, (baby guanacos) are known to spit on keepers from time to time! Be careful out there...
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ma: Manakins are a group of small & stubby birds generally native to the North & Central areas of South America! These birds are very unique, with over 60 species; Each being sexually dimorphic, they are easily distinguishable by both their colours but their behaviour too! These guys are noted for their extremely exuberant courtship displays - some species are even known display in leks, designated locations where groups of males perform together!

The Araripe Manakin, or as the Portuguese called it soldadinho-do-araripe, meaning Little soldier of Araripe. due to its vibrant red crown resembling a helmet. This small bird is nearing the brink of extinction, with the last survey, being conducted in 2018 estimating the remaining population to be around 150-700 mature individuals left, with the largest threat to these colourful birds being habitat destruction, caused by the construction of banana plantations.

Golden-Headed Manakin, just like the other males of the Pipridae family, these birds also have stunning colours contrasting against a majority black plumage, the females and juveniles of the species also closely resemble White-Bearded Manakins of the same gender and age. Golden-Headed Manakins, just like the other species of Manakin engage in co-operative breeding displays, where the males dart along high branches, flapping their wings at high speeds.

The Blue-Capped Manakin, although from a distance the males of this species may look just as bland as the females of the species, just with a new coat of paint, when viewed up close they have a bright crown of pale blue feathers on their heads. This species has managed to baffle scientists as to how they are able to maintain their population, as an estimate of only 7.5% of nests are able to successfully fledge their young.

The Blue-Backed Manakin, not only do these small birds have stunning colouration that can make them stand in almost any exhibit, but they also have an extremely interesting breeding display, with it being more co-operative than competitive, with males working in pairs, jumping off branches alternately and jumping over each other to impress a female.

The Red-Headed Manakin, This species is very similar to the Gold-Headed, with the obvious difference being the colour of its crown, they can be found across northern south america, however not much is known about them past their range

The White-Bearded Manakin, This species can be found across northern south america, with the populations found on the island of trinidad expressing island syndrome, with them being bigger than their mainland counter parts. During mating up to seventy males can be in one group, once they attract a mate the males will puff out their neck feathers to appear larger and more appealing to females.

The White-Collared Manakin, This species is relatively similar to its bearded counterpart, except for a large set of yellow feathers covering its chest. in Panama, this species heavily hybridises with a species of manakin that isn't present in wotw, the Golden-Collared Manakin. with the male off-spring having a yellow collar instead of white, but otherwise being identical to White-Collared Manakins.

The White-Crowned Manakin, Although the males of this species are relatively un-interesting when compared to the other species that wotw has to offer, when comparing the females to the other species there is a clear difference, with white-crowned females having blue-grey markings on the head, shoulders and tips of the tail feathers. with the individuals located near the Andes also sporting red eyes.

The Band-Tailed Manakin, This species can be found throughout central south america, where it inhabits tropical forests and swamps, they are also very similar to the other two species in their genus, being the Wire-Tailed Manakin, and the Crimson-Hooded Manakin. Unfortunately, just like the Red-Headed Manakin, there is very little information past this point.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.sq: Squirrel monkeys are one of the smallest and most attractive New World primates not just in South America, but worldwide. These pretty primates are highly active,  social animals that sprint about the canopy extremely fast; They are active during the day, and rarely come down to the ground. However, they unfortunately fall victim to the Exotic Pet Trade - so conservation efforts are in place to save these primates not just in the pet trade  but in their natural habitats as well.

Collin's Squirrel Monkeys are actually a relatively new discovery -  until a genetic study by Jessica Lynch Alfaro et al. raised them to the species category, Collins’ squirrel monkey had been considered a subspecies of the Common Squirrel Monkey! Similarly to other species, it is a social and gregarious monkey that lives in dynamic and large groups. Between meals, this group will stop to socialize and rest.

The black-capped squirrel monkey is one of five Squirrel Monkey species; Their name comes from the dark crown on top of their heads. Black capped squirrel monkeys feed on a range of fruit, seeds, insects and small animal prey - during the dry season they can depend entirely on animal prey.

The bare-eared squirrel monkey, is a species of Squirrel Monkey endemic to the Amazon basin, primarily in Brazil. While pristine forests are everybody's dream, these new world primates can actually tolerate disturbed habitats, allowing for the unfortunate destruction of the Amazon Rainforest to effect them somewhat less than other species!

The Central American squirrel monkey is the closest you will get to the 'Common Squirrel Monkey,' which is in fact just the collective term for multiple species. This species of Squirrel Monkey are unique for their high pitch calls, known to be heard from over a mile away! This species was also one of the only primates to go to space!

Humboldt's Squirrel Monkey are a species endemic to much of Northern South America - including Brazil, Venezuela and Northern Peru. They are widespread in their range and adapt easily, living in larger family groups than some other species - between 25-50. This species is actually the 'parent' species of 3 other subspecies.

Similarly to other species in the addon, this variant of Squirrel Monkey is not actually a species, however a genetic mutation of one of the 7 species of Squirrel Monkey - Wonders Of The World's is a leucistic mutation of the Central American Squirrel Monkey. Unfortunately, due to their beauty, this variant is bred for in the exotic pet trade.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.wa: With your name starting with the word 'wart', you don't really expect much in the way of looks, and warthogs sure do live up to their names! Quite possibly the ugliest animal on the African Savannah, Warthogs sprout a prominent pair of tusks and rough, grey skin, somewhat similar to that of a Rhinoceros. Warthogs were of course made famous by Ernie Sabella's Pumbaa, a character in The Lion King, where he sings with his meerkat buddy about 'Hakuna Matata' and forgetting your worries!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.py: Pygmy Hippos are the smallest of the Pachyderms, depending on whom you ask. Made extremely famous by the global sensation 'Moo-Deng', a baby hippo born at Khao Kheow Open Zoo in 2024, these astoundingly cute & charismatic animals are the smaller cousin of the Common Hippo, one of the most dangerous animals on the planet. Despite their now global fame, Pygmy Hippos are an Endangered Species, and are threatened by habitat destruction, and pollution of the water sources of which they live.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ha: Hammerkops are one of those birds. A key feature of any african aviary, this wading bird is actually the closest living relative to the Shoebill, a bird also famous for its odd look & size. Hammerkops get their name from the shape of its head, the long bill and crest are reminiscent of a hammer, therefore they are given their name from the Afrikaans word for hammerhead! Many legends exist about these mysterious birds, whom are also renowned for their enormous nest designs!
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.qu: Quetzals are a species of bird native to South America, that are relatively unknown to science. Despite playing a central role in the Mesoamerican mythology and it's association with the Aztec deity Quetzalcoatl, Quetzals are not in the limelight of modern media, and unfortunately are not commonly seen in captivity. These birds are instantly recognisable due to their beautiful and colourful plumage, alongside their long tail.

The Crested Quetzal is a species of Quetzal native to the Tropical Moist Montane Forests of South America. They are currently listed as Least Concern by the IUCN red list, and, similarly to other species, present significant sexual dimorphism.
The Golden-Headed Quetzal is a species of Quetzal found in the Mid-Elevation Forests of Panama & Bolivia. This species is distinguished from other Quetzal species by their distinctive golden heads.

The Pavonine Quetzal, also known as the Peacock Trogon, is a species of bird in the Trogonidae family, native to the lowland rainforests of Eastern South America. They are listed as Least Concern by the IUCN red list.

The Resplendant Quetzal is a species of Quetzal found in the Montane Cloud Forests of Central America & Mexico. Resplendant Quetzals are the national bird of Guatemala, and many South American cultures do not allow them to be hunted or killed.

The White-Tipped Quetzal is a species of Quetzal native to Venezuela, Colombia & Guyana. As their name suggests, they are somewhat distinguished from other species by the tips of their wings, which blend a whiter-type colouration to their plumage.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ki: Kirk’s dik-diks grow to a maximum size of just 40cm, making them one of the smallest species of antelope in the world. They take their name from Sir John Kirk, a 19th century Scottish naturalist, as well as the sound it makes when fleeing from danger. As they make the distinctive ‘dik-dik’ call they make when startled – they jump from their hiding place and move in a series of zig-zag leaps to confuse predators.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ho: Some say honey badgers don’t care, but that reputation is hardly fair. In fact, these medium-size members of the weasel family have super-sized attitudes. Honey badgers, also known as ratels, are related to skunks, otters, ferrets, and other badgers. These voracious omnivores get their name from their fondness for feeding on honey and honeybee larvae.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.so: The southern caracara is a striking bird of prey found across South America, known for its intelligence, adaptability, and opportunistic feeding habits. Unlike many other raptors, caracaras are often seen walking on the ground, scavenging for food, and even using problem-solving skills to access meals. Southern caracaras are part of the falcon family, but their behaviour is quite different from typical falcons.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ca: A pest to ranchers, a prize to hunters, and a temperamental tank to anything that bothers it, African buffalo roam by the thousands in sub-Saharan Africa. Cape buffalo, one of four distinct subspecies of the African buffalo, are the most common. When the buffalo aren’t fighting off the occasional lion, they’re eating grass—and lots of it. It forms the bulk of their diet.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.sa: The Sable Antelope is a remarkable creature native to savanna woodlands and grasslands. Adapted to these environments, the animal boasts a robust physique that enables it to navigate these challenging terrains.  The Sable Antelope’s majestic appearance and remarkable horns have made it an iconic species in the African wilderness. However, these features have also made it a target for trophy hunters.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.ga: The Gaboon viper is the largest viper in Africa. Its coloration and broad head, which mimics a fallen leaf, camouflages it among leaf litter on the forest floor. Though venomous, this snake has a calm nature and rarely bites humans. Most bites occur when the snake is stepped on before it has an opportunity to get away. If harassed, it will raise the upper part of its body and hiss in threat before actually striking.
informational_blurb.wondersoftheworld.or: Oryx are one of the most recognized hoofstock species, and are commonly found in mixed-species exhibits with animals such as Giraffe, Zebra and Rhinoceros - they are undoubtedly a zoo staple! Unfortunately, Oryx have been subject to intense hunting and habitat loss, with 2 species having been previously declared Extinct In The Wild. However, thanks to the work of captive breeding programmes, they have made a return.

Once widespread across Northern Africa, the Scimitar Horned Oryx was declared ‘Extinct In The Wild’ by the IUCN Red List. Since then, they have been the face of captive breeding programmes and represent the pivotal work zoos do to rebuild wild populations. In 2023, the Scimitar Horned Oryx was reclassified as Endangered.

The smallest member of their genus, Arabian Oryx are native to the desert and steppe regions of the Arabian Peninsula. Similarly to their scimitar-horned cousins, Arabian Oryx were classified as ‘Extinct In The Wild’ in the 1970s and were slowly reintroduced in the 1980s. In 2016, populations were estimated at 1,220 individuals in the wild, including 850 mature individuals, and 6,000–7,000 in captivity worldwide.

Beisa Oryx are a medium-sized species of Oryx native from the semideserts and steppes in the Horn Of Africa. They have a brownish grey coat with a white underside, separated by a stripe of black, with black stripes where the head attaches to the neck. This particular species is listed as Endangered by the IUCN status, mainly because of the excessive hunting and habitat destruction.

The largest species of Oryx, Gemsbok are found in the dry bushland regions of Southern Africa, mainly in the Kalahari and Namib Desert. Gemsbok live in herds of about 10–40 animals, which consist of a dominant male, a few nondominant males, and females. Despite currently being listed as ‘Least Concern’ by the IUCn, they are widely hunted for their spectacular horns that can reach 85 cm (33 in) in length.

Fringe-Eared Oryx area species of Oryx found in the acacia woodlands and bushlands of East Africa.  Their main characteristics are their fawn-coloured hair across almost their entire body, with a black stripe down the flanks. Similarly to other Oryx, Fringe-Eared Oryxes travel in nomadic herds, typically composed of 30 to 40 individuals. Unfortunately, they are subject to poaching and habitat loss, so are classified as ‘Vulnerable’ by the IUCN Red List.
